BRENDAN FOSTER ON THE LONDON MARATHON
Every April millions of people around the UK watch the London Marathon, and in sitting rooms up and down the country someone will lean across to their partner and say: "I could do that". 


That's the beauty of the London Marathon and what makes it a unique top-class sporting event - anyone can start running and sign up to take part. 


And it's not just a one-day event, participants have to change their lifestyles, get fit and of course raise millions for charity. 


A healthy contingent of celebrities put themselves through the mill too which is fantastic. 


Seeing Zombie Ramsay or Matt Dawson running 26 miles makes people think: "If he can do it, so can I," and that provides so much encouragement and inspiration. 


For the more serious athletes, the line-up for the men's elite race is arguably the strongest marathon field ever assembled. 


The likes of Haile Gebrselassie, Paul Tergat, Felix Limo and Khalid Khannouchi reads like a Who's Who of distance running. 


For me Gebrselassie is the one to watch. He decided after his glittering track career that the marathon was going to be his event. 


He didn't take to it too kindly at first, but he's adapted his training, approached things differently and is now bang in form. 


As far as British interest is concerned we are once again relying on Jon Brown. 


He has been a great athlete for his country and is our only male world-class marathon runner but I don't expect him to feature, which can also be said of Liz Yelling in the women's elite race. 


Lornah Kiplagat is my favourite for that event after her performance holding off the challenge of the Ethiopians at the recent World Cross Country Championships. 


She will face the might of Berhane Adere and Gete Wami on Sunday, but I think she is strong enough to prevail again. 


Enjoy the race, 


Brendan 


Brendan Foster MBE will be commentating on Sunday's London Marathon (coverage starts at 0830 BST on BBC ONE).

During his athletics career he won an Olympic bronze medal in the 10,000m and broke two world records.
